bestBHT.bht: The contrast is evident between those who claim to know God, yet lack true knowledge, and Jesus who not only knows God but also keeps His word, embodying the perfect union with Him. Jesus exposes their falsehood, highlighting that if He were to deny His knowledge and connection with God, it would be as great a lie as their own false claims. By affirming His deep understanding and obedience to God's word, Jesus stands as the only one who truly knows the Father.

Henry Alford: The sense is, of Whom ye say ‘He is our God,’ and (not “yet” nor “but”) know Him not."

Then what follows sets forth the contrast between them, the pretended children of Abraham, who know not Abraham’s God (the liars), and Him who knows Him, and keeps His word, so that His word works in and by Him.
His allowing their denial of this state of knowledge and union would be as great a lie in Him, as their assumption of it was in them.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 55. I shall be a liar like unto
you—now rising to the summit of holy, naked severity, thereby
to draw this long dialogue to a head.
Marvin Vincent: Saying [λογον] . Properly, word, as ver. 51. So Rev.
Archibald T. Robertson: And ye have not known him...But I know him."
Equip by eternal fellowship to reveal the Father."
This word liar is not considered polite today in public speech when hurled at definite individuals.
John Gill: Yet ye have not known him... they had no spiritual knowledge of him, nor communion with him.
...nor did any know the Father, but the Son, and he to whom he is pleased to reveal him.
But I know him, and keep his saying... do his will, and always the things that please him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The passage highlights the contrast between those who claim to know God but have no true knowledge of Him and Jesus, who truly knows God and keeps His word. Jesus exposes their lies and ignorance, emphasizing that if He were to deny His knowledge and union with God, it would be as great a lie as their false claim. Jesus' deep understanding and obedience to God's word distinguish Him as the only one who truly knows the Father. As Jesus comes to the climax of this dialogue, He uses the word liar to sharply denote the discrepancy between their false claims and His intimate relationship with the Father.

The contrast is evident between those who claim to know God, yet lack true knowledge, and Jesus who not only knows God but also keeps His word, embodying the perfect union with Him. Jesus exposes their falsehood, highlighting that if He were to deny His knowledge and connection with God, it would be as great a lie as their own false claims. By affirming His deep understanding and obedience to God's word, Jesus stands as the only one who truly knows the Father.

Jesus addresses those who claim to know God but lack true knowledge, contrasting them with Himself, who truly knows and keeps God's word. He exposes their deception, highlighting the absurdity of denying His knowledge and union with God. By affirming His deep understanding and obedience to God's word, Jesus sets Himself apart as the only one who truly knows the Father. His use of the word liar underscores the vast discrepancy between their false claims and His genuine connection with God.

Jesus confronts those who falsely claim to know God, while lacking genuine knowledge, by underscoring the contrast between them and Himself. He highlights the incongruity of His denying His knowledge and union with God, which would be as false as their own claims. Jesus establishes His unique understanding and obedience to God's word, portraying Himself as the only one who truly knows the Father. Through His piercing use of the word liar, Jesus exposes the vast difference between their deceit and His authentic connection with God.

Jesus exposes the disparity between those who claim to know God but lack true knowledge, and Himself, who truly knows God and obeys His word. He points out the falsehood of denying His knowledge and union with God, which would be as dishonest as their own claims. Jesus establishes Himself as the sole individual who genuinely knows the Father, emphasizing His deep understanding and obedience to God's word. By using the term liar, Jesus highlights the stark contrast between their deceit and His authentic relationship with God.
